meromorphic functions

Let C∗=C∪{∞}\C^* = \C \cup \set{\infty}C∗=C∪{∞} be the Riemann sphere and let Ω=C∗∖{0,1}\Omega = \C^* \setminus \set{0, 1}Ω=C∗∖{0,1}. Let f ⁣:Ω→Ω\func{f}{\Omega}{\Omega}f:Ω→Ω be a holomorphic function.

  1. Prove that if fff is injective then f(Ω)=Ωf\p{\Omega} = \Omegaf(Ω)=Ω.
  2. Make a list of all such injective functions fff.
Solution.

First, let

φ(z)=zz−1,\phi\p{z} = \frac{z}{z - 1},φ(z)=z−1z​,

which is an automorphism of C∗\C^*C∗ mapping 0↦00 \mapsto 00↦0 and 1↦∞1 \mapsto \infty1↦∞. Thus, if fff is as in the problem, then g=φ−1∘f∘φg = \phi^{-1} \circ f \circ \phig=φ−1∘f∘φ is an injective holomorphic function everywhere except at φ−1(0)=0\phi^{-1}\p{0} = 0φ−1(0)=0 and φ−1(1)=∞\phi^{-1}\p{1} = \inftyφ−1(1)=∞, i.e., g ⁣:C∖{0}→C∖{0}\func{g}{\C \setminus \set{0}}{\C \setminus \set{0}}g:C∖{0}→C∖{0}.

Since ggg is injective, it follows that ggg does not have an essential singularity at ∞\infty∞. Indeed, by the open mapping theorem, g({∣z∣<1})g\p{\set{\abs{z} < 1}}g({∣z∣<1}) is open, and by Casorati-Weierstrass, g({∣z∣>1})g\p{\set{\abs{z} > 1}}g({∣z∣>1}) is open and dense. Thus, g({∣z∣<1})∩g({∣z∣>1})≠∅g\p{\set{\abs{z} < 1}} \cap g\p{\set{\abs{z} > 1}} \neq \emptysetg({∣z∣<1})∩g({∣z∣>1})=∅, which is impossible.

Because ggg omits 000, we know that 1g\frac{1}{g}g1​ is holomorphic. By injectivity, 1g\frac{1}{g}g1​ any 000 of ggg must be simple by the argument principle, so any pole of ggg is simple. Thus, we may write

g(z)=az+b+czg\p{z} = \frac{a}{z} + b + czg(z)=za​+b+cz

for some a,b,c∈Ca, b, c \in \Ca,b,c∈C. Observe that

g(z)=0  ⟺  a+bz+cz2=0  ⟺  z∈{−b+b2−4ac2c,−b−b2−4ac2c}g\p{z} = 0 \iff a + bz + cz^2 = 0 \iff z \in \set{\frac{-b + \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2c}, \frac{-b - \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2c}}g(z)=0⟺a+bz+cz2=0⟺z∈{2c−b+b2−4ac​​,2c−b−b2−4ac​​}

i.e., if a,c≠0a, c \neq 0a,c=0, then ggg has two non-zero roots, which is impossible, so one of them must vanish. If a=0a = 0a=0, then g(z)=b+czg\p{z} = b + czg(z)=b+cz, which means b=0b = 0b=0 or else ggg still has a non-zero root. Similarly, if c=0c = 0c=0, then g(z)=az+bg\p{z} = \frac{a}{z} + bg(z)=za​+b and as before, we need b=0b = 0b=0 in this case. Thus, g(z)g\p{z}g(z) is either az\frac{a}{z}za​ or azazaz for some non-zero a∈Ca \in \Ca∈C. Hence,

f(z)=(φ∘g∘φ−1)(z)=g(φ−1(z))g(φ−1(z))−1=azaz−(z−1)ora(z−1)a(z−1)−z.\begin{aligned} f\p{z} &= \p{\phi \circ g \circ \phi^{-1}}\p{z} \\ &= \frac{g\p{\phi^{-1}\p{z}}}{g\p{\phi^{-1}\p{z}} - 1} \\ &= \frac{az}{az - \p{z - 1}} \quad\text{or}\quad \frac{a\p{z - 1}}{a\p{z - 1} - z}. \end{aligned}f(z)​=(φ∘g∘φ−1)(z)=g(φ−1(z))−1g(φ−1(z))​=az−(z−1)az​ora(z−1)−za(z−1)​.​

In either case, fff is a Möbius transform, so fff is automatically surjective.
